addRequestTimestamp

public SecurityConfigurator addRequestTimestamp(java.lang.String timestamp)
                                         throws XWSSecurityException
Adds a timestamp filter into the request filter chain The result of calling this method is to insert the timestamp into the security header.

Parameters:
timestamp - the timestamp value
XWSSecurityException

addRequestTimestamp

public SecurityConfigurator addRequestTimestamp()
                                         throws XWSSecurityException
Adds a timestamp filter into the request filter chain The result of calling this method is to insert a timestamp element (containing the current time in xsd:dateTime format) into the security header.

XWSSecurityException

Parameters:
timestamp - the timestamp value
XWSSecurityException

addResponseTimestamp

public SecurityConfigurator addResponseTimestamp()
                                          throws XWSSecurityException
Adds a timestamp filter into the Response filter chain The result of calling this method is to insert a timestamp element (containing the current time in xsd:dateTime format) at the current top of the security header.

XWSSecurityException

encryptRequestBody

public void encryptRequestBody(java.security.cert.X509Certificate receiverCert)
                        throws XWSSecurityException
Encrypt the body of the SOAP Document using a random symmetric key The symmetric key is encrypted with the receiverCert and an EncryptedKey element is inserted into the security header. The certificate used is inserted into the security header as a BinarySecurity Token.

Parameters:
receiverCert - the receiver certificate
XWSSecurityException

encryptResponseBody

public void encryptResponseBody(java.security.cert.X509Certificate receiverCert)
                         throws XWSSecurityException
Encrypt the body of the SOAP Document using a random symmetric key The symmetric key is encrypted with the receiverCert and an EncryptedKey element is inserted into the security header The certificate used is inserted into the message as a BinarySecurity Token.

Parameters:
receiverCert - the receiver certificate
XWSSecurityException

signRequestBody

public void signRequestBody(java.security.cert.X509Certificate senderCertificate)
                     throws XWSSecurityException
Sign the body of the SOAP Document The certificate of the signer is sent along with the message as as a Binary Security Token in the Security Header.

Note: The security domain is assumed to be initialized with a keystore containing the signer's private-key and certificate.

Parameters:
senderCertificate - the certificate of the signer
XWSSecurityException

signResponseBody

public void signResponseBody(java.security.cert.X509Certificate senderCertificate)
                      throws XWSSecurityException
Sign the body of the SOAP Document The certificate of the signer is sent along with the message as as a Binary Security Token in the Security Header

Note: The security domain is assumed to be initialized with a keystore containing the signer's private-key and certificate.

Parameters:
senderCertificate - the certificate of the signer
XWSSecurityException

verifyRequestBody

public void verifyRequestBody()
                       throws XWSSecurityException
Verify the signature on the body of the SOAP Document

Note: The security domain is assumed to be initialized with a key/truststore containing the signer's certificate/public-key.

XWSSecurityException

verifyResponseBody

public void verifyResponseBody()
                        throws XWSSecurityException
Verify the signature on the body of the SOAP Document

Note: The security domain is assumed to be initialized with a key/truststore containing the signer's certificate/public-key.

XWSSecurityException

decryptRequestBody

public void decryptRequestBody()
                        throws XWSSecurityException
Decrypt the encrypted body of the SOAP Document Assumes that the security domain is initialized so that the private key can be located given the receiver certificate used for encrypting the symmetric key.

XWSSecurityException

decryptResponseBody

public void decryptResponseBody()
                         throws XWSSecurityException
Decrypt the encrypted body of the SOAP Document Assumes that the security domain is initialized so that the private key can be located given the receiver certificate used for encrypting the symmetric key.

XWSSecurityException

setSecurityEnvironment

public void setSecurityEnvironment(SecurityEnvironment domain)
Set the security domain to be used for requests and responses

addEncryptRequest

public SecurityConfigurator addEncryptRequest(java.lang.String xpath,
                                              boolean content,
                                              java.lang.String keyInfoStrategy)
                                       throws XWSSecurityException
Encrypt the specified xpath element in the SOAP Document, using a random symmetric key. An xenc:EncryptedKey element is inserted into the security header to communicate the symmetric key information to the receiver.

NOTE: Use of this method assumes a Security Domain has been set with appropriate key/trust stores and agreements initialized in it (see description of keyInfoStrategy below)

Parameters:
xpath - the xpath of element to be encrypted
content - flag which if set to true indicates that the element content has to be encrypted and not the element itself.
keyInfoStrategy - the key information for the key used to encrypt the random symmetric key, One of DIRECT_REFERENCE_STRATEGY : direct URI reference to a local Binary Security Token KEY_IDENTIFIER_STRATEGY A reference which denotes a Certificate which has been agreed upon (out of band) and specified in security domain as an agreement called CERT-VALUE
XWSSecurityException

addDecryptResponse

public SecurityConfigurator addDecryptResponse()
Decrypt the encrypted elements in the SOAP Document. Information about the Encryption Key is extracted from an xenc:EncryptedKey element assumed to be present at the top of the security header (at the time of this method call). The encrypted data elements are in turn identified from the xenc:ReferenceList element inside the xenc:EncryptedKey

addDecryptRequest

public SecurityConfigurator addDecryptRequest()
Decrypt the encrypted elements in the SOAP Document. Information about the Encryption Key is extracted from an xenc:EncryptedKey element assumed to be present at the top of the security header (at the time of this method call). The encrypted data elements are in turn identified from the xenc:ReferenceList element inside the xenc:EncryptedKey

addEncryptResponse

public SecurityConfigurator addEncryptResponse(java.lang.String xpath,
                                               boolean content,
                                               java.lang.String keyInfoStrategy)
                                        throws XWSSecurityException
Encrypt the specified xpath element in the SOAP Document, using a random symmetric key. An xenc:EncryptedKey element is inserted into the security header to communicate the symmetric key information to the receiver.

NOTE: Use of this method assumes a Security Domain has been set with appropriate key/trust stores and agreements initialized in it (see description of keyInfoStrategy below)

Parameters:
xpath - the xpath of element to be encrypted
content - flag which if set to true indicates that the element content has to be encrypted and not the element itself.
keyInfoStrategy - the key information for the key used to encrypt the random symmetric key, One of DIRECT_REFERENCE_STRATEGY : direct URI reference to a local Binary Security Token KEY_IDENTIFIER_STRATEGY A reference which denotes a Certificate which has been agreed upon (out of band) and specified in security domain as an agreement called CERT-VALUE
XWSSecurityException

addSignRequest

public SecurityConfigurator addSignRequest(java.lang.String xpath,
                                           java.security.cert.X509Certificate cert,
                                           java.lang.String keyInfoStrategy)
                                    throws XWSSecurityException
Sign the specified xpath element in the SOAP Document, and use the certificate in cert to insert the key information in the signature.

NOTE: Use of this method assumes a Security Domain has been set with appropriate key/trust stores and agreements initialized in it (see description of keyInfoStrategy below)

Parameters:
xpath - the xpath of element to be signed
keyInfoStrategy - the key information for the key used to sign One of DIRECT_REFERENCE_STRATEGY : direct URI reference (wsse:Reference) to a local Binary Security Token created from the Certificate in cert is inserted into the KeyInfo sub-element of the ds:Signature. The created Binary Security Token is inserted into the security header above the signature element. KEY_IDENTIFIER_STRATEGY A reference (wsse:KeyIdentifier) which denotes the Certificate in cert is inserted into the KeyInfo sb-element of the ds:Signature element.
XWSSecurityException

addVerifyResponse

public SecurityConfigurator addVerifyResponse(boolean isDirectRef)
verfiy the signature on the signed elements in the SOAP Document. Information about the signed elements is extracted from the SignedInfo The signature element is assumed to be present at the top of the security header (at the time of this method call).

When the ds:KeyInfo is a wsse:KeyIdentifier, then the security domain is used to locate the certificate corresponding to the KeyIdentifier.

Parameters:
isDirectRef - flag which when set to true indicates the key information (in ds:Keyinfo) for verification is a direct reference to a Binary Security Token in the Security Header. A false value indicates the key information is a wsse:KeyIdentifier, containing the encoded subjectkey identifier of the signer.

addSignResponse

public SecurityConfigurator addSignResponse(java.lang.String xpath,
                                            java.security.cert.X509Certificate cert,
                                            java.lang.String keyInfoStrategy)
                                     throws XWSSecurityException
Sign the specified xpath element in the SOAP Document, and use the certificate in cert to insert the key information in the signature.

NOTE: Use of this method assumes a Security Domain has been set with appropriate key/trust stores and agreements initialized in it (see description of keyInfoStrategy below)

Parameters:
xpath - the xpath of element to be signed
keyInfoStrategy - the key information for the key used to sign One of DIRECT_REFERENCE_STRATEGY : direct URI reference (wsse:Reference) to a local Binary Security Token created from the Certificate in cert is inserted into the KeyInfo sub-element of the ds:Signature. The created Binary Security Token is inserted into the security header above the signature element. KEY_IDENTIFIER_STRATEGY : A reference (wsse:KeyIdentifier) which denotes the Certificate in cert is inserted into the KeyInfo sb-element of the ds:Signature element.
XWSSecurityException

addVerifyRequest

public SecurityConfigurator addVerifyRequest(boolean isDirectRef)
verfiy the signature on the signed elements in the SOAP Document. Information about the signed elements is extracted from the SignedInfo The signature element is assumed to be present at the top of the security header (at the time of this method call).

When the ds:KeyInfo is a wsse:KeyIdentifier, then the security domain is used to locate the certificate corresponding to the KeyIdentifier.

Parameters:
isDirectRef - flag which when set to true indicates the key information (in ds:Keyinfo) for verification is a direct reference to a Binary Security Token in the Security Header. A false value indicates the key information is a wsse:KeyIdentifier, containing the encoded subjectkey identifier of the signer.
